sn18.1:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn18.1:1.3: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn18.1:1.4: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
sn18.1:2.2: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn18.1:2.4: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn18.1:2.6: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn18.1:2.7: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn18.1:3.11: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn18.1:3.13: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn18.1:3.14: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn18.1:4.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, the ear, the nose, the tongue, the body, and the mind.
sn18.1:4.2: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn18.1:4.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn18.1:4.4: (The ten discourses of this series should be treated in the same way.)
